Description: Immunotherapies have revolutionized the primary care of cancer patients. Cellular therapies are emerging as an important pillar of cancer immunotherapies. However, T cell-based approaches face a wide range of limitations e.g., the requirement for autologous cell products and immune-related adverse events. In contrast, allogenic innate lymphoid cell-based therapies could overcome these limitations, as they hold promise to be cost effective with scaled manufacturing for multi-dosing, on demand off-the-shelf availability and less toxicity. To develop an effective product that expands, persists and maintains anti-tumor functions in patients, we need to better understand the complex phenotypic plasticity, heterogeneity and function of innate lymphoid cells. In this session, we will discuss the use of pre-clinical mouse models and human samples to study innate lymphoid cell biology as well as recent clinical advances.
SearchResultBody: SY11. Innate Lymphoid Cells in Cancer
Title: Innate Lymphoid Cells in Cancer
